Synergism studies on alumina-supported copper-nickel catalysts towards furfural and 5-hydroxymethylfurfural hydrogenation Sanjay Srivastava G.C. Jadeja Jigisha Parikh ⁎ Department of Chemical Engineering, Sardar Vallabhbhai National Institute of Technology, Surat 395007, Gujarat, India Department of Chemical Engineering Sardar Vallabhbhai National Institute of Technology Surat Gujarat 395007 India ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Present contribution focuses on the structural and performance studies on alumina-supported copper-nickel catalysts for hydrogenation of furfural and 5-hydroxymethylfurfural towards 2-methylfuran and 2, 5-dimethylfuran which are used as biofuels additives. The structure of alumina-supported copper-nickel catalysts prepared by impregnation method was studied by using a combination of various characterization techniques including XRD, N2-sorption, TEM, H2-TPR, NH3-TPD, XANES/EXAFS and CHNS methods. A series of characterizations revealed that dispersion of copper increases with an increase in nickel loading on ɣ-Al2O3 due to strong interaction between nickel and copper oxide particles. This also led to the formation of mixed copper-nickel oxides in calcined catalysts at the highest loading of nickel and copper (i.e. Cu/Ni=1). In catalytic activity, both the monometallic Cu/ɣ-Al2O3 and Ni/ɣ-Al2O3 showed lower activity and selectivity towards hydrogenation of both Furfural and 5-Hydroxymethylfurfural to 2-methylfuran (2-MF) and 2, 5-dimethylfuran (DMF), respectively. However, with increase in nickel loading, the activity and the selectivity of Cu/ɣ-Al2O3 drastically increased for both the cases and Cu-Ni/ɣ-Al2O3 (Cu/Ni=1) showed the highest catalytic activity. Furthermore, combination of Cu/Ni ratios and temperature plays a significant role in the product distribution, as in the case of furfural hydrogenation, at a lower temperature, furfuryl alcohol (FOL) appears as the main product while at a higher temperature, 2-methylfuran (2-MF) is found to be the dominant product over Cu-Ni/ɣ-Al2O3 (Cu/Ni=1) catalysts. Similarly, 2,5-bishydroxymethylfuran (BHF) is found to be the major product at a lower temperature and 2,5-dimethylfuran (DMF) is selectively produced at a higher temperature in the HMF hydrogenation. Furthermore, reaction pathways are discussed for both the reactions. Keywords Furfural 5-Hydromethylfurfural Cu-Ni 2-Methylfuran 2,5-Dimethylfuran 1 Introduction Over the years, valorization of abundantly accessible biomass derived commodities such as furfural (FAL) and 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) to fuel and other value-added chemicals has been the focus of academic research in lieu of the reduction of our dependence on fossil resources and to minimize the environmental pollution caused by the increasing level of CO and CO2 in the atmosphere [1,2]. FAL and HMF are the platform chemicals which can be obtained by acid hydrolysis of C-5 and C-6 sugars such as xylose and cellulose [3,4]. FAL and HMF can be upgraded to value added chemicals and fuel additives via different processes such as hydrogenation, hydrogenolysis, etherification, aldol-condensation and acetallization [5–8]. Hydrogenation followed by hydrogenolysis of FAL and HMF is the most studied process for the conversion of FAL and HMF towards bio-fuel additives such as 2-methylfuran (2-MF), 2-methyltetrahydofuran (MTHF), Pentane and 2,5-dimethylfuran (DMF), respectively [9–16]. Hydrogenation of FAL gives a variety of products which are used as important industrial chemicals and as gasoline additives such as FOL, 2-MF, MTHF, tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol (THFOL), cyclopentanone, furfurylamine, 1,5-pentanediol, and so on (Scheme 1 ). Amongst them, the synthesis of FOL and 2-MF has been receiving attention owing to their wide range of applications. FOL is widely used in the resin industries for the synthesis of epoxy resin, liquid resin, and as a modifier for phenolic and urea resins. It is also used in the making of acid resistant bricks, corrosion proof fibre glass, anti-corrosion fibres concrete, lysine, vitamin C, lubricants, and plasticizers [17–19]. 2-MF has been recently used as a gasoline blend in standard vehicles, as perfume intermediates, chloroquine lateral chains in medical intermediates, and as a raw material for the production of crysanthemate pesticides [12,13]. Similar to FAL, HMF is also known to be a resourceful chemical which is used to form a variety of products (Scheme 2 ). However, it is particularly known for the synthesis of DMF which is used as a gasoline blend due to its high energy density (30kJcm−3) and research octane number (RON) of 119 [14]. Over the last two decades, various chromium-free and noble-metal free catalysts have been developed for the conversion of both FAL and HMF [12,13,16–23]. Normally, noble metal catalysts are found to be highly active even at mild reaction conditions. However, due to FAL and HMF being adsorbed and activated on the surface of noble metal through the model of η2 (C,O)-coordination, the very high activity of these catalysts usually lead to high selectivity for some undesirable side reaction such as CC hydrogenation [5]. In this context, Cu-catalysts exhibited highly efficient hydrogenation of biomass-derived FAL and HMF on which adsorption proceeded via η1 (O)-coordination model wherein, η1 (O)-surface species is generated to bound the active metal, leading to high hydrogenation activity towards CO bond and therefore, further hydrogenolysis of CO bond [12,13,21]. The deactivation of Cu-based catalysts is associated with the sintering and leaching of copper species. The addition of a second metal (Co, Ni, or, Fe) improves the activity, selectivity and the stability of copper-based catalysts for liquid-phase catalytic reactions. In our previous work, we have successfully demonstrated the role of Co in enhancing the dispersion of Cu over supported Cu catalysts for hydrogenolysis of FAL to MF [12]. The present work has been undertaken based on the above background. Herein, we aimed to explore chromium-free and noble metal-free alumina supported Cu-Ni catalysts for the hydrogenation of furfural and 5-hydroxymethylfural. The structure of Cu-Ni catalysts was studied by using a series of characterization techniques such as XRD, BET, TEM, NH3-TPD, H2-TPR, XANES/EXAFS and CHNS analysis. The Cu-Ni/ɣ-Al2O3 catalysts were found to be efficient for the hydrogenation of biomass derived FAL and HMF, which respectively led to the selective production of 2-MF (84% yield) and DMF (56% yield) under mild conditions. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Metal salts such as copper nitrate (Cu(NO3)2·3H2O) and nickel nitrate (Ni(NO3)2·6H2O), chemicals such as 5-hydroxymethylfurfural, 5-methylfurfuryl alcohol, furfural, furfuryl alcohol, 2-methyl furan, 2-methyltetrahydrofuran, 2-pentanone, 2-pentanol, 2, 5-dimethylfuran, and tetrahydrofuran were of GC grade, purchased from Sigma-Aldrich Mumbai, India. Support ɣ-Al2O3 (99% pure) was purchased from a Sterling Chemical Pvt. Ltd. Surat India. 2.2 Catalysts synthesis and characterization The bi-metallic catalysts were prepared by impregnation method by using respective metal salts. The Cu-Ni/ɣ-Al2O3 catalysts containing fixed (Cu=10wt%) and varying Ni loadings of 10, 5, and 2.5wt%, respectively, are denoted as Cu-Ni/ɣ-Al2O3 (Cu/Ni=1), Cu-Ni/ɣ-Al2O3 (Cu/Ni=2) and Cu-Ni/ɣ-Al2O3 (Cu/Ni=4). In order to study the textural and structural properties of prepared catalysts, all the samples were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), BET-surface area, H2-temperature-programmed reduction (TPR), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), NH3-temperature-programmed desorption (TPD), X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XANES/EXAFS), and CHNS analysis. Detailed procedure regarding the synthesis and characterization of supported bimetallic copper-nickel catalysts is provided in the Supplementary information. 2.3 Catalytic activity 2.3.1 Hydrogenation of furfural The catalytic hydrogenation of FAL was carried out in 100mL stainless steel autoclave with a magnetic stirrer, a pressure gauge and automatic temperature control. In a typical experiment, 1.0g of catalyst was reduced by passing H2 at 300±2°C and 0.1MPa for 3h. The reactor was cooled down to room temperature and flushed with N2. Then 4.32g of FAL in 20mL of 2-propanol was added and charged into the reactor. The catalytic activity of prepared catalysts was investigated at 130–220°C and 4.0MPa with stirring speed at 1000rpm. Product samples were analyzed using a Sigma GC system with FID detector. AB-5 capillary column with dimension of 30m×0.25mm×0.5μm was used. In a typical procedure, the initial oven temperature was held at 80°C for 4min and increased up to 220°C with the ramp of 20°C/min and hold for 4min 1μL of liquid product was injected into the capillary column by using the split ratio of 20:1, where nitrogen was used as a carrier gas. 2.3.2 Hydrogenation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural Same apparatus was used for the catalytic hydrogenation of HMF. Prior to reaction, 0.5g of catalyst was reduced by passing H2 at 300±2°C and 0.1MPa for 3h. Then calculated amount of substrate (0.2g of HMF in 20mL of THF) was added and charged into the reactor. The catalytic activity of prepared catalysts was investigated at 130 and 200°C, and 3.0MPa with stirring speed at 1000rpm. Each experimental run was repeated twice for ensuring reproducibility. The product samples were analyzed using Sigma GC system with FID detector. AB-5 capillary column with dimension of 30m×0.25mm×0.5μm was used. In a typical procedure, the initial oven temperature was held at 50°C and increased up to 180°C with the ramp of 10°C/min, and further increased up to 280°C with the ramp of 5°C/min and hold for 2min 1μL of liquid product injected into the capillary column by using the split ratio of 20:1, where nitrogen was used as a carrier gas. 3 Result and discussion 3.1 Structure evaluation of catalysts 3.1.1 X-ray diffraction The supported bi-metallic Cu-Ni/ɣ-Al2O3 (Cu/Ni=1, 2 and 4) catalysts were characterized using XRD to recognize the crystalline phases. The XRD spectra of calcined and reduced catalysts are illustrated in Figs. 1 & 2 respectively. In case of calcined samples, the broad peak observed at 2θ=67.2° for all the catalysts is corresponding to a reflection of ɣ-Al2O3 (JCPDS: 86-1410) [12]. All three catalysts displayed sharp diffraction peaks at 2θ =35.6° and 38.7°, corresponding to the planes (111) and (111) of monoclinic copper oxide (JCPDS 80-1917, 45-0937) [17]. The two diffraction peaks at 2θ =37.3° and 43.3°, corresponding NiO (JCPDS 78-0643) [24]. The average crystallite size of NiO was calculated by line broadening of (100) of NiO at about 2θ=43.3° using Scherrer’s equation and found to be <15nm. Likewise, the average crystallite size of CuO was calculated by line broadening of (111) of CuO (JCPDS 80-1917) at about 2θ=35.6°. The size of CuO was found to be 35nm for Cu-Ni/ɣ-Al2O3 (Cu/Ni=4) catalyst which decreased to 20nm for Cu-Ni/ɣ-Al2O3 (Cu/Ni=1). This shows that the adding up of Ni precursor promoted the dispersion of CuO species and reduced the CuO crystallite size drastically from 35nm to a size of (<20nm). The crystal phase evolution of reduced Cu-Ni/ɣ-Al2O3 catalysts with different Cu/Ni ratios was also observed in the wide angle domain to further look at the structure of bimetallic catalysts. The catalysts were activated by adopting the same procedure as reported in our previous work [12]. In brief, all the samples were reduced in an autoclave by using external hydrogen at 300°C and 0.1MPa for 3h. The reduced samples were kept in a vacuum desiccator till further analysis with XRD. The recorded XRD spectra are shown in Fig. 2. It can be deduced that copper oxide is almost reduced to copper metal in presence of Ni at 300°C. The featured diffraction lines of Cu metal, i.e., (111), (200), and (220) (FCC structure), were noticeable at 2θ =43.6°, 50.8°, and 74.4°, respectively in all the three catalysts (JCPDS 04-0836) [17]. Furthermore, the reduction of CuO to Cu metal increased with an increase in Ni content from 2.5 to 10wt% which was further justified by XANES/EXAFS analysis. Other than metallic Cu, two noticeable diffraction spectra at 37° and 44.3° ascribed to NiO and Ni or Cu, correspondingly. It is noteworthy that the 2θ values of Cu° and Ni° are almost similar; consequently it is not easy to make a distinction among them at 2θ=44.3° [24]. Moreover, mixed CuNiO solution might be shaped owing to the similar FCC structures with similar lattice parameters [29]. Thereby, it can be figured out that the reduced samples are having NiO and metallic Ni or Cu species. These observations are consistent with the previous reports on bimetallic Cu-Ni catalysts [24–32]. Furthermore, in order to get clarity in the case of the bimetallic samples, a progressive shift of the metallic phase peak (the position of the Cu (220) reflection) is observed with an increase in the Ni loading (Fig. 2) which suggests the formation of Cu-Ni alloy due to synergy between Cu and Ni metals. Notably, a similar trend was previously reported in the literature which revealed the formation of bimetallic alloy by varying the composition of Cu/Ni [28,29]. 3.1.2 N2-sorption analysis Textural properties of all the synthesized catalysts are shown in the Table 1 . The support ɣ-Al2O3 featured a BET of 161m2/g and a total pore volume of 0.54mL/g [12]. The surface area and pore volume of the impregnated catalysts decreased with respect to bare ɣ-Al2O3, attributed to the relatively high metal loading (10wt.%), wherein, Ni/Cu particles might block the pores of ɣ-Al2O3 during metal impregnation which in turn decreased the pore volume of catalysts. Furthermore, when all three bimetallic catalysts were compared, it was observed that the surface area, the pore volume of bi-metallic catalysts increased with increasing amounts of Ni and Cu-Ni/ɣ-Al2O3 (Cu/Ni=1) showed the maximum values (ref. Table 1). The strong interaction between Cu and Ni might be facilitating the dispersion of Cu. The BET results are consistent with the XRD results which revealed that Cu dispersion is enhanced with increase in Ni loading. On considering the XRD results, it could be postulated that Ni loading has a strong influence on the stabilization of the copper nanoparticles because any apparent diffraction peaks allocated to CuO could not be observed, which showed that the incorporation of nickel species could prevent the agglomeration of copper species, leading to an increase in surface area with an increase in Ni loading [33,34]. It was further justified from TEM analysis that after activation in hydrogen, the metal species dispersed evenly on the surface of the support when Ni was at its maximal loading. 3.1.3 Transmission electron microscopy Fig. 3 demonstrates the TEM micrograph of alumina supported Cu-Ni/ɣ-Al2O3 catalysts with various (Cu/Ni=1, 2 and 4) ratios reduced under H2 at 300°C. From a pictorial view, it was observed that the dispersion of metal particles increased over alumina support with adding up Ni species and aggregation of metal particles appeared to be minimum in Cu-Ni/ɣ-Al2O3 (Cu/Ni=1). It was interesting to see that Ni modified (Cu/Ni=4) catalyst contained two kinds of metal species, highly dispersed metal particles having smaller size and segregated clusters (Fig. 3f). With further increased nickel content, an optimized dispersion of copper species could be observed (Fig. 3b). Moreover, Cu-Ni/ɣ-Al2O3 (Cu/Ni=4) revealed the formation of bigger crystallites in the range of 25–35nm. However, as Ni loading increases from (2.5wt%) to (10wt%) i.e., (Cu/Ni=4) to (Cu/Ni=1) the size of crystallites found to be decreased in the range from 25−35nm to 10−15nm with uniform distribution of metal nanoparticles (Figs. 3 & 4 ). This is consistent with the XRD results. The diffraction peaks of Cu (FCC) decreased with Ni loading and Ni peaks were very weak, indicating the presence of smaller particles. These observations are well matched with reported literature on bi-metallic Cu-Ni catalysts [31]. To further estimate the composition of doped metals, energy dispersive scattering analysis was carried out. The results showed the presence of Ni and Cu in appropriate proportions. The corresponding metal loadings are presented in Table 1. The results were in agreement with the actual loading amounts used in the synthesis procedure within acceptable errors. 3.1.4 H2-temperature program reduction Fig. 5 shows the reduction patterns of monometallic Cu, Ni and bi-metallic Cu-Ni (Cu/Ni=1, 2 and 4) catalysts supported on γ-Al2O3. The low temperature reduction (150–280°C) profile of CuO on ɣ-Al2O3 was observed. This reduction pattern might either follow a one-step reduction Cu2+ →Cu° mechanism or proceed through an intermediate Cu+ state. The peak located at a lower temperature (190°C) is attributed to the reduction of highly dispersed CuO on γ-Al2O3, while the peak at a higher temperature (260°C) represents the reduction of bulk CuO particles. The Ni/γ-Al2O3 showed broad multiple reduction peaks. This might be attributed to the presence of mixed NiOx species, resulting via distinct interaction of NiO with γ-Al2O3. Furthermore, the different reduction temperatures could be partially ascribed to a different size of NiO particles. In general, on Ni-catalysts, the low temperature peaks are attributed to the reduction of the NiO particles weakly interacting with the support, while the high temperature peaks are confined to the reduction of NiO species in intimate contact with the Al2O3 and/or attributed to the new structure of NiAl2O4 [35]. The reduction profiles of bimetallic Cu-Ni catalysts are found to be much different from their monometallic counterparts; exhibited reduction peaks between them which clearly suggest the synergy between CuO and NiO oxides. It is interesting to see that the H2 consumption peak corresponding to NiO reduction shifted to a lower temperature, and that of CuO shifted to a higher temperature as illustrated in Fig. 5. It was reported that the ultimate integration of Ni2+ into the CuO framework results in a slight narrowing of the lattice owing to the smaller radius of Ni2+ than that of Cu2+ [33]. Naghash et al. reported that the reduction temperature of NiO greatly reduces (<300°C) in presence of Cu and the reduction of NiO was more likely catalysed by metallic copper [36], as pure nickel oxide is typically reduced at above 450°C. On the other hand, the maxima related to copper oxide reduction was progressively shifted to higher temperature (275–295°C) on increase in Ni loading. This can be explained by the two possible reasons; (1) the positive influence of NiO addition on the CuO dispersion by the dilution effect [37,38] and/or (2) the synergistic effect between Ni and Cu [39]. These observations are consistent with XRD, BET, TEM and further XANES/EXAFS analyses. 3.1.5 NH3-Temperature programmed desorption The surface acidity of supported bi-metallic Cu-Ni/ɣ-Al2O3 catalysts with various (Cu/Ni=1, 2 and 4) ratios was determined by NH3-TPD experiments. Generally, catalysts show three types of surface acidity which has been classified as weak (<523K), medium (523–623K) and strong (>623K) acidity based on desorption of ammonia with respect to temperature. In the present work, we have used commercial ɣ-Al2O3 as a support to bimetallic Cu-Ni catalysts having the total acidity of 0.28mmol of NH3/g of catalyst [12]. It is worth noting that presence of five different types of OH groups on the surface of ɣ-Al2O3; exhibits a distinct “net electric charge” (σ), depending on the number of Al neighbours and on Al coordination [40,41]. The removal of OH groups during high temperature treatment (calcination) creates co-ordinatively unsaturated surface (cus) cations where tetrahedral (Al IV) and octahedral (Al VI) aluminium co-ordinations are the most widely accepted [42–44]. Therefore, both type of acidity such as Lewis and Bronsted may exist on ɣ-Al2O3 depending on the degree of dehydration. The quantity of these acid sites may vary with the loading of Cu and Ni. The ammonia desorption profiles for Cu–Ni/ɣ-Al2O3 (Cu/Ni=1, 2 and 4) were found to be very broad that can be de-convoluted to many peaks (Fig. 6 ). Cu-Ni/Al2O3 (Cu/Ni=4) showed broad NH3-desorption peak starting from 150°C to 600°C with maxima at 380°C, being de-convoluted to many desorption peaks attributed to weak, medium and strong acidity. Although, both Cu-Ni/ɣ-Al2O3 (Cu/Ni=2) and Cu-Ni/Al2O3 (Cu/Ni=1) showed broad humps starting from 140°C to 730°C having many shoulder peaks ascribed to all three acidic sites (weak, medium and strong). However, the intensity of maxima desorption increases with increase in Ni loading resulted in the highest acidity (weak, medium and strong) in Cu-Ni/ɣ-Al2O3 (Cu/Ni=1) catalyst. The increase in acidity with increase in Ni loading may be attributed to the (1) synergy between Cu and Ni, (2) synergy between NiO and support material; increased with increase in Ni loading due to poor reduction of NiO at present conditions. The weak and medium acid sites which are increased with Ni loading act as active sites and would contribute to hydrogenolysis of the saturated CO band. Table 2 shows the total acidic sites present in all the three catalysts. As discussed above, the total acidity of Cu-Ni/Al2O3 catalysts increased with Cu/Ni ratio as Cu-Ni/ɣ-Al2O3 (Cu/Ni=4) contained 0.89 (mmol/g cat), Cu-Ni/ɣ-Al2O3 (Cu/Ni=2) contained 1.95 (mmol/g cat) and Cu-Ni/ɣ-Al2O3 (Cu/Ni=1) contained the highest 3.44 (mmol/g cat). 3.1.6 X-ray absorption spectroscopy The Cu-K XANES and derivative XANES spectra of alumina supported Cu-Ni/ɣ-Al2O3 catalysts (calcined at 450°C and reduced at 300°C) with various Cu/Ni (1, 2 and 4) ratios were compared with CuO and Cu-foil (Fig. 7 ). The XANES results for calcined catalysts point out the presence of Cu2+ in the bulk of CuO which is characterized by the edge position located at near 8990eV. The XANES spectrum of CuO displayed two characteristic features of Cu2+ (3d9) compounds with a pre-edge absorption at 8979eV, and shoulder at 8986eV that determines 1s→4p ‘shake-down’ transition in copper (ref. Fig. 7b) [12]. On a closer scrutiny, relative to crystalline CuO, the shape of all three bi-metallic calcined catalysts is found to be different from that of CuO. The intensity of first peak decreases with an increase in Ni loading (Fig. 7a), inferring a change in the coordination environment, i.e., bimetallic Cu-Ni nanoparticle formation. These results are in good agreement to the results obtained by XRD and H2-TPR. The XANES results of reduced catalysts showed the presence of metallic Cu, and have the similar absorption energy pattern as that of the copper edge of a copper foil (8979eV) (ref. Fig. 7c). It was clearly observed that the intensity of a first peak in XANES derivative (ref. Fig. 7d) increases with Ni loading due to the enhanced dispersion of Cu and the formation of bi-metallic Cu-Ni alloy. The quantity of CuO and Cu (0) can be estimated from the XANES spectrum by Linear Combination Fitting in the Athena program [45]. Cu foil and CuO are used as reference materials to fit the data of reduced catalysts. The LCF results are summarized in the Table 3 . It was observed that incorporation of Ni metal improves the reducibility of bi-metallic catalysts as Cu-Ni/ɣ-Al2O3 (Cu/Ni=1) has maximal Cu (0). Nevertheless, we have studied Ni-K edge XANES of fresh calcined and reduced Cu-Ni/ɣ-Al2O3 (Cu/Ni=1), and were compared with NiO and Ni-foil so as to determine the reduction of NiO (Fig. 8 ). The fresh calcined Cu-Ni/ɣ-Al2O3 (Cu/Ni=1) catalyst showed similar spectra which is characterized by NiO spectrum. However, XANES spectra of reduced Cu-Ni/ɣ-Al2O3 (Cu/Ni=1) was slightly shifted towards lower energy level, and its pre-edge appeared probably near the Ni-foil. Thereby, Ni-K edge XANES spectra indicated the presence of NiO in fresh calcined catalyst and a partial reduction of NiO to Ni metal in reduced catalyst. These results are consistent with the XRD, H2-TPR results which evident for the presence of Ni metal. Furthermore, the Cu-Kedge EXAFS analyses of CuO and bi-metallic Cu-Ni/ɣ-Al2O3 having the various Cu/Ni ratios of 1, 2 and 4 were carried out in order to confirm the formation of a bimetallic Cu-Ni alloy in calcined catalysts which are presented in Fig. S1. Lower intense radial allocation peaks for the second and third Cu-Cu coordination shells at 2.54 and 3.01Å in the calcined catalysts indicate smaller sizes of CuO particles and higher Debye–Waller factor [46]. Note that the Fourier transform modulus of the Cu-Ni/ɣ-Al2O3 (Cu/Ni=1) catalyst with smaller copper content is rather different from the EXAFS Fourier transform modulus of CuO and other two samples Cu-Ni/ɣ-Al2O3 (Cu/Ni=2) and Cu-Ni/ɣ-Al2O3 (Cu/Ni=4). In addition, first peak assigned to the Cu-O co-ordination was shifted to higher radial distance might be correspond to incorporation of Ni2+ into the CuO framework that might be resulted the formation of Cu-Ni alloy at the highest loading (Cu/Ni=1) [33]. 3.2 Catalytic activity 3.2.1 Hydrogenation of furfural Hydrogenation of FAL was extensively studied over supported and un-supported Cu catalysts [10–19]. Nagaraja et al. [47] proposed that the presence of more Cu metal and Cu+, as opposed to CuO, promoted high selectivity towards FOL. Therefore, present work focuses on the synergy between Ni and Cu in order to determine the dispersion of Cu and enhanced Cu active sites for FAL hydrogenation. In this work, Cu-Ni/ɣ-Al2O3 catalysts with different (Cu/Ni=1, 2 and 4) ratio are examined at two different temperatures, viz. 130°C and 200°C at 4.0MPa. The results were compared with monometallic Cu/ɣ-Al2O3 (10wt%) and Ni/ɣ-Al2O3 (10wt%) (Table 4 ). On monometallic Ni/ɣ-Al2O3 (10wt%), the conversion was very low (22% at 130°C and 32% at 200°C) (Table 4, Entries 9 &10). These results are very much expected due to poor reduction of NiO to Ni at present conditions as NiO reduces at a temperature >400°C. On the other hand, at 130°C on monometallic Cu, the conversion of FAL was recorded nearly 64% (Table 4, Entry 1). This FAL conversion increases with Ni loading and reached (92%) (Table 4, Entry 3). However, at a high temperature of 200°C, the conversion of FAL increases from 64% to 94% over monometallic Cu and accordingly it reached 100% with the lowest amount of Ni (i.e. Cu/Ni=4) and further remained constant for all Cu/Ni ratios which have been used in the present study. Although, at a higher temperature (200°C) further increase in Ni loading was found to be insignificant towards FAL conversion, yet, to a certain extent, these observations suggested that both metal loading and temperature could be the important factors in enhancing the activity of Cu-catalysts for FAL hydrogenation. The hydrogenation on Cu is expected to be less due to the much lower affinity of the Cu surface for H2 dissociation [48]. Increase in the activity for bi-metallic Cu-Ni catalysts may be attributed to a hydrogen spill-over effect by Ni to Cu sites where the aldehyde hydrogenation reaction takes place. Hydrogen spill-over has been studied in a number of bimetallic systems where a more active metal is used to activate molecular hydrogen; the atomic hydrogen then diffuses to the less active metal sites. This less active site can then be the site of reaction [48]. Recently, Pang et al. also reported synergistic effect in Cu-Ni catalysts in hydrogenation reactions due to a hydrogen spillover effect from Ni to Cu [49]. This argument regarding hydrogen spillover is also consistent with a recent report published over bimetallic Cu-Ni catalysts [50]. Also, it is well known that temperature accelerates the rate of reaction towards the forward direction and at a higher temperature; the conversion was close to 100% that cannot be further increased. Hence, it is necessary to recognize the individual role of both the Ni loading (synergy between Ni and Cu) and temperature that might play an important role in FAL hydrogenation [12]. Moreover, to get clarity about synergy between temperature and metal active sites, the activity was compared in the kinetic regimes for different catalysts for the hydrogenation of both FAL and FOL (Fig. S4). As observed, at a constant temperature (200°C), the conversion of FAL increased rapidly at the start of reaction and reached about 55% in 15min over Cu-Ni/ɣ-Al2O3 (Cu/Ni=1) which further increases linearly with time (ref. Fig. S4, a). Additionally, it can be seen that the conversion of FAL was increased with Ni loading at the respective time i.e., 35% over Cu-Ni/ɣ-Al2O3 (Cu/Ni=4) to 55% over Cu-Ni/ɣ-Al2O3 (Cu/Ni=1). On contrary, FOL converts slowly from the start of reaction and followed the similar trend for Cu/Ni ratios as observed in FAL hydrogenation (ref. Fig. S4, c). Nevertheless, the distinct conversion of FAL and FOL over all three catalysts suggested that the conversion was influenced by the synergy between temperature and metal active sites. These observations regarding FAL and FOL conversion via CO and CO bond scission are well matched with the previous reports available for the hydrogenation of FAL [10,18,19,47]. However, As far as selectivity is concerned, two major products, viz. FOL and 2-MF were observed with a small amount of by-products like MTHF, THFOL, Furan etc. Herein, similar to FAL conversion, product selectivity was also altered with increase in both the Ni loading and the temperature. At a lower temperature (130°C), FOL was the main product with 72% selectivity over monometallic Cu. This selectivity towards FOL was further increased with an increase in Ni loading and reached 93% over Cu-Ni/ɣ-Al2O3 (Cu/Ni=1). However, at a high temperature of (200°C), the selectivity towards FOL significantly dropped and the formation of 2-MF increases from 8% to 54% over monometallic Cu and further reached to 81% over Cu-Ni/ɣ-Al2O3 (Cu/Ni=1) (Table 4, Entry 6). The above results were compared with monometallic Ni, it was observed that it did not produce even traces of 2-MF at 130°C but at a higher temperature nearly 5% MF was obtained. Thereby, it can be concluded that Ni catalysed the FAL towards selective production of FOL and little of THFOL, Furan, etc. for both the temperatures. In order to look at the influence of Cu/Ni ratio on the selectivity of 2-MF on various catalysts, the 2-MF selectivity from both FAL and FOL was plotted at the kinetic regimes (Fig. S4, b&d). In case of FAL, it was observed that initially the selectivity towards 2-MF was low due to the presence of intermediate FOL which was further converted to 2-MF as reaction prolonged. Also, the selectivity towards 2-MF increased with Cu/Ni ratio and maximal incremental 2-MF formation was observed at Cu/Ni=1. However, for FOL hydrogenolysis, initially 2-MF was selectively formed over both mono and bimetallic catalysts wherein, Cu-Ni/ɣ-Al2O3 (Cu/Ni=1) showed the maximum selectivity of 98% within 15min which was slightly dropped 88% at 60min (ref. Fig. S4, d). Additionally, for 2-MF selectivity, similar trends were clearly observed for different Cu/Ni ratios. In order to validate the argument discussed above about the synergy between Cu and Ni; the most influential parameter involved in our bimetallic catalytic system, the TOF (turnover frequency, S−1) values for the formation of FOL and 2-MF via FAL and FOL hydrogenation respectively, were also evaluated (ref. Table S1). TOF values for hydrogenation of FAL to FOL are apparently larger than that of FOL hydrogenolysis to 2-MF in all the catalysts, which suggests that the second reaction may be the rate-determining step for the conversion of FAL to 2-MF in the present catalytic system. In particular, TOF values for both the reactions over bimetallic catalysts are noticeably greater than that of monometallic counter-parts, which proposed the synergy between Cu and Ni that improved the catalytic activity. The drastic change in the selectivity towards various products can be explained by considering the role of both the temperature and the structural changes occurred in the catalysts after being loaded with Ni. A series of characterization techniques such as XRD, BET, H2-TPR and XANES study revealed that with an increase in Ni loading, the dispersion of Cu increases and ultimately reduces the size of Cu grain which is an important factor for CO hydrogenolysis [13]. In addition, at the highest loading of Ni, mixed Cu-Ni alloy was also formed which was responsible for this enhanced activity. It is well known and reported many times in the literature that synergy between transition metals led to enhance the dispersion and/or structural properties of active species and ultimately altered the activity and selectivity. Also, sometimes it was evident that there is an alloy formation within the bimetallic catalyst system that may be responsible for the improved activity of catalysts compared with their monometallic counterparts. It was reported that the formation of Ni-Cu alloy is able to enhance the mobility of surface lattice hydrogen at high temperature and become a more activated step in hydrogenation [51]. According to d-band vacancies theory the binding energies of Ni and Cu changes during alloy formation [52]. This is also supported by s-p-d re-hybridization in Cu-Ni catalysts wherein, both Ni and Cu gain an assessable amount of d charge in alloy formation [53]. This helps in filling of the un-occupied d-band of Ni by Cu after complete filling of d band of Cu. It has been found in the literature that a combination of bimetallic composition, the binding energy, and the bonding morphologies in the bimetallic surface structure significantly altered the hydrogenation activity in selectively tailored hydrogenation reactions including CO and CC reduction [54,55]. Furthermore, in combination with surface acidity (ref. Fig. 6, Table 2), it was evident that the weak sites as well as total acidity increases with Ni loading. Thereby, combining with structural properties and surface acidity, it can be deduced that at a lower temperature mostly metal particles might be playing the role which are known to break the CO bond present in FAL and resulting in FOL as a major product. However, at higher temperature CO bond is polarized due to high activation energy as well as due to activation of the weak acid site at 200°C. These weak acid sites are accountable to promote CO bond hydrogenolysis owing to the strong oxophilic nature [13]. In addition, with an increase dose of Ni, a small amount of furan was also observed. These observations are in consistent with previous reports for FAL hydrogenation [12,13,16,19,56]. 3.2.1.1 Effect of temperature on the activity of Cu-Ni/ɣ-Al2O3 (Cu/Ni=1) for FAL hydrogenation Influence of the reaction temperature for FAL hydrogenation over Cu-Ni/ɣ-Al2O3 (Cu/Ni=1) is shown in Fig. 9 . It was interesting to see that the reaction temperature plays an important role in the product distribution. The general trend observed for liquid phase hydrogenation involving furfural and H2 using Cu-Ni catalysts is that hydrogenation dominates at lower reaction temperatures (<170°C), giving FOL as the major product. However, at a high temperature (>200°C) further conversion of FOL to 2-MF, MTHF or furan takes place. As usual, FAL conversion increased from 92% (130°C) to 100% (200°C) and remained constant with any further increase in temperature. In fact, it was observed that the selectivity towards 2-MF at a lower temperature (130°C) was very low, due to the presence of the intermediate FOL. It is worth noting that higher temperature promotes the CO hydrogenolysis for the cleavage of the carbonyl group due to the higher activation of the CO bond [56,57]. Therefore, the rise in temperature is much more prominent for the –CH2−OH hydrogenolysis of the intermediate FOL. 3.2.1.2 Reaction pathway of furfural hydrogenation The hydrogenation of FAL to FOL has been studied extensively, however, only limited reports are available on underlying the reaction pathway, especially for the hydrogenolysis of FOL to 2-MF. In our previous work [12], we have briefly discussed that over Cu-catalysts CO bond preferentially hydrogenated giving FOL which is further converted into 2-MF by hydrogenolysis. In this work, we have studied hydrogenation of FAL and FOL in the temperature range of 130–230°C at 4.0MPa in order to look in to the reaction pathways using Cu-Ni/ɣ-Al2O3 (Cu/Ni=1) (ref. Figs. 9 &10 ). The results of both the FAL and FOL hydrogenation revealed a similar trend for the selectivity towards 2-MF. The selectivity of 2-MF increased with increasing temperature and reached the maximum of 84%. Afterwards, based on the products that were detected in GC spectra, a catalytic hydrogenation pathway has been proposed in Scheme.1. It was found that FAL was initially hydrogenated to form the intermediate product FOL via preferential adsorption of FAL on to the Cu(111) surface, which subsequently underwent the hydrogenolysis to 2-MF as reported earlier [57b]. However, a small amount of furan was also observed at higher temperature, which might be due to the presence of Ni metal via decarbonylation of FAL [57a]. Considering the above observations, it is proposed that hydrogen molecule undergoes dissociative adsorption as hydrogen atoms on the catalyst surface (Cu and Ni). It is assumed that in a first step, the acidity of the catalyst attracts the lone pair of aldehyde oxygen that helps in the adsorption of FAL on the Cu (111) catalyst surface in a preferred orientation [57b]. Second step involves the addition of hydrogen atom to carbonyl oxygen atom to form hydroxyl alkyl intermediate, which on further addition of hydrogen atom gives FOL. Further, –CH2−OH oxygen helps in adsorption of this intermediate FOL on the catalyst surface in a preferred orientation similar to the case of FAL adsorption The formation of 2-methylfuran occurred through hydroxyl alkyl intermediate followed by removal of water molecule (leaving group). 3.2.2 Hydrogenation of HMF In order to illustrate the role of Cu/Ni ratio on the catalytic activity in the liquid-phase hydrogenation of HMF, bi-metallic Cu-Ni/ɣ-Al2O3 with (Cu/Ni=1, 2, and 4) were screened over two different reaction temperatures such as 130°C and 200°C and 3.0MPa. The results were compared with their monometallic counterparts Cu/ɣ-Al2O3 (10wt%) and Ni/ɣ-Al2O3 (10wt%) which are presented in Figs. 11 & 12 . At a lower temperature (130°C), HMF conversion of ∼56.2% was obtained over monometallic Cu/ɣ-Al2O3. With an increase in Ni loading, HMF conversion increases and reached the maximum value of 70.6% over Cu-Ni/ɣ-Al2O3 (Cu/Ni=1) catalyst. As far as selectivity is concerned, BHF was found to be a dominant product and its selectivity increases with increase in Ni loading and it reached a maximum of 88.4% over Cu-Ni/ɣ-Al2O3 (Cu/Ni=1) catalyst. These results can be attributed to the increased number of metallic Cu sites which are increased with increasing Ni loading (ref. Table 3). Furthermore, these experimental findings revealed the incapability of Cu-Ni catalysts for hydrogenolysis of CO and OH bond at a lower temperature of 130°C. However, Cu-Ni catalysts showed slightly decarbonylation ability and produced FOL. Literature disclosed that along with hydrogenation and hydrogenolysis, decarbonylation followed by ring opening products were also obtained especially on Ni and Pt metals. First, FOL was obtained via decarbonylation of HMF which was further converted into C4 & C5 ring opening products as reported in the furfural hydrogenation over the same metals [58,59]. In addition, over bifunctional Ni and Pt catalysts, C6 ring opening products were also reported. In the present work, we observed the formation of 2-MF; via decarbonylation of HMF to FOL followed by CO hydrogenolysis of FOL to 2-MF. Furthermore, at higher temperature of 200°C, the conversion of HMF was increased from 56.2 to 92.7% over Cu/ɣ-Al2O3 and all three bimetallic Cu-Ni catalysts showed about 99% conversion of HMF. These results might be attributing to the increase in the reaction rate, facilitated by the breaking of CO bond over metallic Cu at higher temperature [58–62]. It was reported that the bond energy of CO, and the bond energy of CC are 715kJmol−1 and 615kJmol−1, respectively, making the hydrogenation of the CC bond much easier than the CO bond [62]. However, the presence of a conjugated furan ring makes the hydrogenation of the CO bond relatively easier than the CC bond in the selective hydrogenation of HMF into DMF which is promoted by higher temperature. However, it was observed that further loading of Ni was insignificant to the conversion of HMF as all the catalysts showed similar activity. Moreover, Ni/ɣ-Al2O3 (10wt%) was found to be very less active for HMF hydrogenation too, wherein, it displayed very low conversion (nearly 14% at 130°C and 19% at 200°C) (Figs. 11 & 12). A series of characterization presented in this work well supported these observations which were already discussed in previous section. Similar to FAL hydrogenation, role about synergy between temperature and metal active sites was also explored for HMF hydrogenation at the kinetic regime for different catalysts (Fig. S5,a). In contrast to FAL hydrogenation, initial HMF conversion was found to be slow, which speeds up further with time. However, conversion trend observed was found to be almost similar to FAL hydrogenation. In context to product distribution at 200°C, hydrogenation of the CO bond followed by hydrogenolysis of CO and OH in HMF was favored, resulting in DMF as a major product and BHF, 5-MF, 5-MFOL as minor products over bi-metallic Cu-Ni catalysts [61]. However, BHF (45.4% and 71% selectivity) still appeared as a major product over both the monometallic Cu and Ni, respectively. It was reported that BHF is the major intermediate over all the metals and especially over transition metals which was further converted into DMF via intermediate 5-MFOL at higher temperature via subsequent hydrogenation and hydrogenolysis reactions [20,21,63,64]. According to literature, this could not be possible over only Cu metal which required either the acidity or early transition metal oxides [10–21]. Therefore, it could be suggested that the synergy between Cu-Ni sites as evident in XRD, BET, TPR and XANES/EXAFS results in the present bi-metallic Cu-Ni catalysts and temperature can lead to hydrogenation/hydrogenolysis reaction towards HMF to DMF. In order to validate the argument, selectivity towards DMF was plotted at the kinetic regimes. It was observed that selectivity towards DMF was increased with increase in Cu/Ni ratio with respect to time (Fig. S5, b). Interestingly, two different reaction pathways were observed, one is the hydrogenation of CO bond and the other is decarbonylation of CC. The hydrogenation of CO bond followed by hydrogenolysis of CO and OH leading to the formation of DMF via intermediate BHF, 5-MF, 5-MFOL. The DMF selectivity increased with Ni loading from 46.2 to 56.6% from CuNi (Cu/Ni=4) to Cu-Ni (Cu/Ni=1). The selectivity of FOL also increased from 12.2 to 17.4%, resulting in lowered selectivity towards DMF. These observations are well matched with the previous reports, wherein partially reduced NiO acts as active sites for decorbonylation reaction [64]. 3.2.2.1 Reaction pathway of HMF hydrogenation Scheme 2 displays the possible reaction pathways for the HMF conversion which was drawn considering the GC spectra obtained over the present catalytic system. As HMF contains three functional groups in its structure, namely CO, OH, and a furan ring (refer. Scheme 2), and therefore, hydrogenation of HMF is found to be a very complex reaction. The product distribution depends on the temperature, H2-pressure, catalysts and solvent [14,64,65]. In the present work, we observed that HMF first undergoes hydrogenation of CO bond and produced a diol intermediate such as BHF. Furthermore, hydrogenolysis of BHF leads to the formation of DMF via intermediate 5-MFOL. These observations are in consistent with the previous reports [20–23]. On the contrary, a small amount of 5-MF was produced via parallel hydrogenolysis reaction probably on acidic sites. Literature revealed that initial hydrogenolysis in HMF only occurs over bifunctional catalysts or in the presence of strong acid such as H2SO4, HCl, formic acid etc [15,63]. It was observed that the reduction of CO and OH is difficult over CO on Cu, and Ni. However, along with hydrogenation/hydrogenolysis, decarbonylation followed by ring opening products were also observed. These observations are well matched with previous reports published especially on Ni and Pt metals [20–23]. Wherein, FOL was first produced via decarbonylation which was further converted into 2-MF via hydrogenolysis of a CO bond as reported in the FAL hydrogenation over the same metals. In addition, C6 ring opening products were also reported, which might be due to the presence of Ni. 3.2.3 Stability and reusability of the catalyst Cu-Ni/ɣ-Al2O3 (Cu/Ni=1) catalyst that exhibited the best catalytic efficiency was recycled three times to evaluate its stability for hydrogenation of FAL to 2-MF. The used catalyst without calcinations (3nd Cycle, dried at 100°C in an oven) is characterized using TEM, XRD, and CHNS analysis in order to examine the characteristic of used catalysts (refer Figs. S3 & S2, and Table S2). The XRD pattern of used catalyst somewhat resembles the characteristic features of Cu-Ni/ɣ-Al2O3 (Cu/Ni=1) catalyst; displayed the similar peaks assigned to most stable Cu metal species in the spent catalyst, as indicated by the diffraction peaks at 2θ =43.6°, 50.8°, and 74.4°, which were respectively indexed as (111), (200), and (220) (FCC structure) [17] no peak corresponding to carbon was observed (Fig. S2). However, the XRD peaks related to Ni, NiO and CuO were also appeared may be due to surface segregation of metallic particles. The XRD result of used catalyst is well supported by TEM and CHNS analyses, which revealed the absence or little presence of carbon (Fig. S3, Table S2). Besides the Cu characteristic features, however, TEM and XRD revealed that the size of particles slightly increased after 3nd cycle which may be the reason for a drop in the selectivity of catalysts. In order to explore the recyclability of Cu-Ni/ɣ-Al2O3 (Cu/Ni=1) catalyst, the used catalyst was separated from a reaction mixture and dried at 100°C for overnight in the oven. The hydrogenation of furfural was then performed over the used catalyst without calcination (Fig. 13 ). A slight decrease in conversion of furfural (nearly 5–6% up to 3rd cycle) was observed. However, the selectivity towards 2-MF was found to be decreased to nearly 30% might be due to increase in the size of metal nanoparticles which favored the formation of FOL and have poor hydrogenolysis ability [13]. Also, it was reported that small amount of Ni addition prevent Cu catalysts from coke at the mild conditions [29]. Thus, it could be concluded that catalyst is active and stable during the hydrogenation of furfural with little expense of 2-MF selectivity. Therefore, it is suggested that the agglomeration of metal particles should be prevented during reaction and considered as a future task in synthesis bimetallic Cu-Ni catalysts for FAL hydrogenation. 4 Conclusion In the present work, the performance of Cu-Ni/ɣ-Al2O3 bimetallic catalysts on the furfural and 5-hydroxymethylfurfural under mild operating conditions was studied. A series of characterization techniques offered a comprehensible portrait of the origin of active sites in alumina supported Cu-Ni catalysts to be synthesized. XRD, TPR and XANES/EXAFS indicated a rise in dispersion of copper in the presence of nickel over alumina support due to strong interaction between nickel and copper oxide particles. Further, TPR measurements showed a much easier reduction of copper in the presence of nickel. The catalytic system was found to be capable towards 100% conversion of the FAL and HMF under mild conditions and also furnished almost 84% and 56% selectivity towards the production of biofuel additives such as 2-MF and DMF, respectively. As far as Cu/Ni ratio concerned, the superior catalytic performance of Cu-Ni/ɣ-Al2O3 (Cu/Ni=1) catalysts could be attributed to the highly dispersed Cu species. In addition, the temperature played a significant role in driving the selectivity towards a desired product. At lower temperature, only FOL and BHF appeared as a major product due to hydrogenation of CO bond present in FAL and HMF, respectively. However, at a high temperature further hydrogenolysis of both the intermediates lead to the formation of desired products such as 2-MF and DMF, respectively. Eventually, it can be concluded that appropriate combinations of transition metal and temperature can lead to the selective hydrogenation of FAL and HMF to 2-MF and DMF which is a valuable step in search of precious metal free and environmentally benign catalysts for the development of biofuels production process. Ultimately, it could be concluded that catalyst is active and stable during the hydrogenation reactions only if the growth of metal particles size could be prevented during reaction that may be considered as a future task in the synthesis of bimetallic Cu-Ni catalysts for hydrogenation reactions. coredata.dc:description: The structure of alumina-supported copper-nickel catalysts prepared by impregnation method was studied by using a combination of various characterization techniques including XRD, N2-sorption, TEM, H2-TPR, NH3-TPD, XANES/EXAFS and CHNS methods. A series of characterizations revealed that dispersion of copper increases with an increase in nickel loading on ɣ-Al2O3 due to strong interaction between nickel and copper oxide particles. This also led to the formation of mixed copper-nickel oxides in calcined catalysts at the highest loading of nickel and copper (i.e. Cu/Ni=1). In catalytic activity, both the monometallic Cu/ɣ-Al2O3 and Ni/ɣ-Al2O3 showed lower activity and selectivity towards hydrogenation of both Furfural and 5-Hydroxymethylfurfural to 2-methylfuran (2-MF) and 2, 5-dimethylfuran (DMF), respectively. However, with increase in nickel loading, the activity and the selectivity of Cu/ɣ-Al2O3 drastically increased for both the cases and Cu-Ni/ɣ-Al2O3 (Cu/Ni=1) showed the highest catalytic activity. Furthermore, combination of Cu/Ni ratios and temperature plays a significant role in the product distribution, as in the case of furfural hydrogenation, at a lower temperature, furfuryl alcohol (FOL) appears as the main product while at a higher temperature, 2-methylfuran (2-MF) is found to be the dominant product over Cu-Ni/ɣ-Al2O3 (Cu/Ni=1) catalysts. Similarly, 2,5-bishydroxymethylfuran (BHF) is found to be the major product at a lower temperature and 2,5-dimethylfuran (DMF) is selectively produced at a higher temperature in the HMF hydrogenation. Furthermore, reaction pathways are discussed for both the reactions.
coredata.dc:title: Synergism studies on alumina-supported copper-nickel catalysts towards furfural and 5-hydroxymethylfurfural hydrogenation
coredata.prism:publicationName: Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical
